text: LETITIA DAVIS, 70's, seated at a piano. The score in fron her is THE BRINDISI from LA TRAVIATA, which she is checki She starts to play. FELICITY LIDDLE, 70’s, page turner, i standing nearby. Reveal BOBBY SWANSON, 70’s, conductor, gesturing and whispering musical terms. All we may hear i

(whispering) .-..allegretto - She starts again. MUSIC continues throughout credits - INT. ANNE LANGLEY’S ROOM - EARLY MORNING A FINGER stirs gargle into a glass of water. The glass is then raised to the mouth of ANNE LANGLEY, 70, soprano. Sh takes a mouthful and gargles. While vocalising, the piano kicks into an ORCHESTRATION of the Brindisi, which continues -
A CARIBBEAN NURSE'S HANDS (DWAYNE, 20's/30’s) bandaging a female leg, (OCTAVIA, 70's, CHORUS). She sits ina wheelchair, holding the score, mouthing the words in Italian. MUSIC continues -

CECILY (CISSY) ROBSON, 70, contralto, bosomy and bountiful, walking the width of the swimming pool rotating her arms. SHERYL, 30's, nurse, standing nearby. CISSY has a CD player above water, corded around her neck, while listening to the Brindisi with earphones on, moving her lips. As she emerges from the pool, SHERYL helps her don a bathrobe. MUSIC continues - INT. FITNESS ROOM —- EARLY MORNING WILFRED (WILF) BOND, 70, baritone, and a few residents, a doing yoga. WILF mouths the score he’s holding, while bei stretched by a FEMALE NURSE, TRACY, 30’s, all the while appreciating her form. MUSIC continues - INT. LEO’S ROOM—- EARLY MORNING A MALE HAND (LEO'S, 70’s) draws a bow across a single str of a cello. The string is tightened. The bow is drawn aga Better. MUSIC continues -

CEDRIC LIVINGSTONE, 70's, former counter-tenor, opera director and self-proclaimed critic, applying rouge to hi cheeks, completing his otherwise light street make-up. He powders, while checking the score next to him. He checks time, 7.40 am, rises in his dressing gown, crosses to his closet and selects a caftan from his wall-to-wall collect MUSIC continues -

REGINALD (REGGIE) PAGET, 70's, tenor, trim, fit, half-moo glasses on the end of his nose, holds the score, vocalisi while standing in front of a mirror adjusting his cravat. MUSIC continues - INT. OLLY FISHER’S ROOM - EARLY MORNING OLLY FISHER, 70's, clarinettist. He tightens a reed onto mouthpiece, practices a phrase, grimaces. OLLY stops mid- phrase. ORCHESTRATION halts. Silence. He inhales and exha with great concentration. Overlap NOBBY chatter -

NOBBY, gardener, 50ish, drinks coffee and talks to SIMON, 20, while pushing a wheelbarrow filled with weeds alongside BEECHAM HOUSE. We might pick up a word or two of what he’s saying. SIMON follows his directions. NOBBY continues to chatter as he points to a brick or stone. SIMON picks it up and brings it to him. NOBBY practices a curl, puts it in the wheelbarrow. He continues to walk next to the house, a handsome mansion. Mysterious and inviting. NOBBY hears LETITIA in the COMMON ROOM, practicing the Brindisi. He looks in, sees vaguely and slightly distorted, people milling about, finding seats, faint chatter.

THE 30 or so ELDERLY OPERA SINGERS of Beecham House taking their seats, including OCTAVIA, in a wheelchair, aided by SHERYL. Some hold scores. Among them REGGIE, CISSY, WILF, GEORGE and HARRY. Some musicians carry their instruments - TONY ROSE, 70’s trumpet and DAVE TRUBECK, 70's pianist, DAPHNE MORGAN, 60's, harpist, LEO CASSEL, cellist, and CEDRIC. DR. LUCY COGAN, 30's, attractive, sits on the side, with ANNE LANGLEY. CEDRIC, seated on a throne-like chair, nods to BOBBY. All on BOBBY. He taps a pencil, raises it, nods to LETITIA. FELICITY, beside her, nervous, as she prepares to turn t pages. LETITIA plays the introduction to the Brindisi. BOBBY cue the chorus. No-one sings. Some RESIDENTS are amused, othe confused. BOBBY whispers to LETITIA. Watching, eyes narrowed, CEDRIC, not happy. BOBBY again cues the residents and they begin to sing. They give it their all. During this, FELICITY fumbles turning a page. LETITIA, irritated, nods repeatedly. FELICITY recovers. At the end, BOBBY finishes with a flourish, then turns to CEDRIC. All look at him expectantly. He keeps them waiting, then:
Nowhere near to where you should be, Bobby. BOBBY nods, continues.

(looks to WILF in the chorus ) Wilf, I couldn’t work out what you were doing, you were much too fast and we had awful ensemble problems there. Can we hear it from Bar 42? LETITIA and FELICITY, flustered, look for it in the score BOBBY alert, cues them.

(taking the mickey, sings a tad and stops) It’s too fast Bobby. Sorry Cedric. (starts again, stops) Too slow Bobby. Sorry Cedric. (starts again, stops) Now it’s too fast Bobby. Sorry Cedric. Some CHORUS MEMBERS giggle.
Silenzio. You never followed the conductor, did you? You always thought you were superior.
I am. NIGEL, 70's, BARITONE, sings the phrase that CEDRIC requested. WILF stares him down as CEDRIC smiles.
Thank you, Nigel. Lotte, in bars 17, 18, 19, you were flat.
No, I don’t think I was. I think the piano needs tuning.
(looks at ANNE LANGLEY) Anne, would you mind singing it?
(as she’s getting up) I don’t do chorus, Cedric. (walking toward the door) I’m going to have my breakfast.
(watches her go, turns to
Cissy, you're still not certain of the words. We only have a month and a half -
(mischievously) That’s six weeks, isn’t it, Reggie?
(CEDRIC gives them a hard look) Yes, six weeks, three days -
- one hour -
Give or take a minute -
And seconds out! CISSY tries to untangle her earphones.
(enunciates each word) Cissy - please - pay - attention.
Ready.
(sarcastically) Of course you are. (MORE)

Will all members of the Gala Committee - and remember that includes you, Cissy - please note that there’s an emergency meeting at twelve noon sharp! I don’t use the adjective, “emergency,” lightly. I will start as the hour strikes. He totters out on his ivory cane motioning to BOBBY to follow him. Much chatter.
Don’t forget to remind me, Reggie-

I’ll set the alarm. As REGGIE sets his watch, OCTAVIA starts to sing. Her voi is remarkably strong but at one point, she forgets the words, and substitutes “Dee-dee-dee-dee.” She stops, embarrassed. The other singers remain respectful.

The residents are eating their breakfasts. Some are being served coffee. DWAYNE doles out pills to various RESIDENT SHERYL, sits next to OCTAVIA. Two Polish waitresses, MART and EVA, chat in Polish to each other as they clear. They start to clear the plate of DAPHNE MORGAN who is finishin her porridge. At her table are TONY ROSE and DAVE.

Wait, wait! (takes another two mouthfuls then pushes the bowl towards them) Thank you. EVA and MARTA, unphased, continue chatting in Polish and on to other tables, passing ANNE LANGLEY and then GEORGE, Chorus. GEORGE is observing an argument going on at a tab next to a window where REGGIE and CISSY are sitting, her earphones by her side. At the only other table by the win sits CEDRIC, LETITIA, and BOBBY. CISSY glances out the window. It’s the chorus vs. the soloists. HARRY is standing between REGGIE and an empty chair (WILF’S). HARRY makes a few attempts to move the chair to seat himself, but REGGIE holds firmly with one hand and one leg, as he continues to do The Telegraph crossword. The following argument should be overlapped -
(from the other table) You can’t save seats, Reg! REGGIE ignores GEORGE, holding fast to the chair with on and one hand while he continues to do the crossword.
(trying to pull the seat) You soloists come in and just sing a few arias. We sing the entire bloody opera.

(pulls back) You may be on stage the entire time, but you're not actually singing, you're just standing in the back. HARRY begins to argue back and REGGIE overrides him. REGGIE (CONT’D) (indicates people at his table) Why now, Harry? We’ve been sitting at this table for as long as I’ve been here. WILF has entered the dining room, supported by his cane, waving to others as he goes toward his table.

Exactly my point! If this place shuts down in six months, which it bloody well could - (he looks at others in the room) I want to be able to look back and remember I had a fucking window seat! As WILF reaches the table, a few cheers from GEORGE and other chorus residents seated at their tables.
Excuse me. He moves the empty chair over and sits in it with difficu holding his cane. HARRY goes back to his table, sits, sta to take his pills.
I could have had a window seat, but I much prefer to sit by myself. CISSY, a bit unnerved, puts her earphones on.
You can’t deny it, Wilf, soloists would be nothing without us.
If I hear that again, Harry, I may stick a fork up your jacksy.
(sitting next to
He’s right, Wilf.
Anybody got a fork?
You know he is-
Make that two forks. ANGELIQUE, 20, French, has brought WILF a full English breakfast. He is getting his usual special treatment from ANGELIQUE as other plates are getting cleared.
Merci, Angelique. Have you done something new to your hair?
No. It’s the same. I just put fringe in front.
I love your fringe in front. REGGIE looks up from his paper.
Extra slice fried bread this morning and your favourite- (places jam on his tray) - apricot Jam. REGGIE lowers his paper and looks steelily at ANGELIQUE.

Dr. Cogan she say too much of the sugar is bad for you, but I know you like very much. Same for Madame Langley. With a wink, she nods in the direction of ANNE LANGLEY, who sits at a nearby table eating delicately.
You’re an angel, Angelique. C’est magnifique. Vous fancy a rumpy- pumpy cette soiree, Angelique?
Qu’est que c’est “rumpy pumpy”?
Angelique, are we getting married or not? I need your answer.

(used to it) Bon appetit! She goes. REGGIE lowers his paper, stares at her. CISSY looks out of the window. CEDRIC, at the next table, leans over and taps her. She removes her earphones and lo at CEDRIC.
Ready.
Cissy, remember, the emergency meeting is at twelve noon. Precisely. CISSY nods, turns back, puts earphones on.
(turns to CEDRIC) Cedric, it’s breakfast time. CEDRIC motions towards CISSY’s back. He rotates his finge indicating CISSY is unbalanced.

Cedric! Chill! Hullo or bonjour, look — He points to the window. DR. COGAN is speaking urgently to TADEK, as they walk past the window. TADEK carries a window squeegee and a cloth. WILF watches them. EXT. DRIVE, BEECHAM HOUSE - WILF’S POV - DAY A people carrier is in the driveway. On the side of the vehicle:
DR. COGAN leaves. TADEK cleans the windows. He gets in th van and starts it.
All looking out the window.
(to REGGIE) Didn’t you say today’s the day?
What’s today?
(to CISSY) Tadek setting off to fetch the new arrival.
At least now we’1ll know who it is.
(excited) What? What? Is there to be a new arrival?
Cissy, we've been talking about it for days.
Have I? Have we? Then who is it? How do you know it’s today?
They’d only send the van for a star.
They sent a private car with a chauffeur for me.  10
When I came I had to pay for my own taxi.
It’s the replacement for poor old Laurence Timms. Dear oh dear, I do miss him. (they eat) But I’1l tell you this, I never knew a man to fart like Laurence.
Wilf, please. Concerned that it will offend CISSY, REGGIE looks at her. But to his dismay, CISSY is smiling, enjoying WILF’S story.
That man could fart at will -
Please, I’m eating my breakfast.

I’m not making this up Reg. - he would get down on the floor on all fours, go into a meditative state, until his entire body relaxed. At which point he could actually inhale and exhale through his anal canal-
Willllf!! CISSY sees NOBBY in the garden. WILF notices CISSY watchi NOBBY.
- and when he exhaled, it came out as a crepitation. That’s what he called it. What a gentleman! His record was one hundred and thirty- seven crepitations in a row.
(resigned) I give up.  11

(to CISSY, teasing) Cissy, will I do instead of Nobby for a quick one in the long grass? CISSY, continuing to listen to her CD, turns back to her breakfast but her napkin falls from her lap. WILF is about to retrieve it but doesn't, so that CISSY has to lean down, revealing her ample cleavage. WILF observes CISSY'S bosom while putting apricot jam on his toast. WILF (CONT’D) May I tell you, Cissy, in all honesty, that you still have the most beautiful tits I’ve ever seen? CISSY finds her napkin, sits up, triumphant, smiling.

(Takes a bite of his toast.) In fact, your whole body causes me to pulsate with lust. She smiles, blithely, as REGGIE glares at WILF'S toast. WILF (CONT’D) (to REGGIE) Pass the apricot jam, old son- REGGIE controls his irritation. CISSY reaches across and passes the jam to WILF and returns to her CD.
Breakfast over, the residents continue to make their way slowly out of the dining room. The maids continue to clea while NIGEL, on his way out, passes WILF and REGGIE who a getting up from the table.
For the record Wilf, Cedric was right, you were too slow.
Stick it where the sun don’t shine, Nigel. LETITIA and FELICITY, the pianists, appear at REGGIE’s an WILF’s side. The following is overlapped -
Do any of you yet know what you propose to do for the gala?  12
I was thinking of giving my Figaro.
You must let me know in plenty of time.
Felicity dear, I’m the pianist. I’m the one who plays the score. You're the one who turns the pages. FELICITY and LETITIA walk away.
I’m still a professional and I can’t bear it when you’re annoyed with me. CISSY stops at LOTTE’S table.
I didn’t think you were out of tune at all.
Anne, what are you going to do for the gala?
What? She continues to eat.
What are you going to do for the gala? She spontaneously begins to sing an aria from TOSCA - Vissi D'Arte.  13
(to REGGIE, sotto voce) Sorry I asked.

The Beecham House van is parked in front of one of the elegant houses on the street. Bottles of milk are being delivered to the house next door. Above, JEAN HORTON, at her flat window, is watching. TADEK and the BUILDING ATTENDANT emerge carrying suitcases and load them into the van. The ATTENDANT stays with the van as TADEK goes back to the house.

INT. JEAN HORTON’S FLAT - DAY WIDE SHOT on her back, silhouetted, revealing again JEAN HORTON, mid 70s, air of a grande dame, standing alone nea a window in her living room, empty of furniture, dust mar where pictures once hung. There are sealed trunks and suitcases on the ground with decals of different countrie She is smartly dressed but in somewhat dated clothing. TADEK comes in to collect more suitcases.
Be careful with that one, it’s fragile.
I come back for trunk. And for you. TADEK leaves. JEAN continues to stare out the window.
The people carrier making its way along the country road. TADEK at the wheel. JEAN in a rear seat, lost in forlorn thought. She has been writing on the back of a newspaper. She mouths words softly.
- I apologise - be kind to me - we were different then - no, no - we were - I can't do this -  14
(glancing in the rear mirror) Madam, you say to me something? JEAN is suddenly overcome with alarm:
Stop! Turn round. Go back -
What? What? You wanna go back? No, no, I must call Dr. Cogan -
(confused, in a state) Don’t be such a damn fool, drive on!
Madam, what you want? Stop, go, what?
WILF, on the chair lift, holding a remote control, descends slowly while humming. He sees a dazzling bunch of garden flowers being arranged in a vase by DR. COGAN. DAPHNE is helping.
Never seen you arrange flowers before, Dr. Cogan.
Really Wilf, haven’t you noticed that we’ve had to cut down on staff in the last few months?

Is it for a new arrival? (No answer, with his remote, he pauses the chair lift) Is that a new skirt? I haven't seen it before. It really clings to you beautifully. It actually accentuates your already beautiful legs. Don’t you agree, Daphne? DAPHNE, embarrassed, demurs.
(amused) You're overstepping the line, Wilf.  15
I know. WILF dismounts the chair lift.
Go for your walk, Wilfred.
I'd love it if you could join me, Lucy.
Go for your walk.
passing her) I must tell you Lucy, it’s hard to leave you.
(continues arranging flowers) Do your best.
May I? WILF picks a flower and tries to put it in his lapel.
I can’t see it without my glasses. Would you be so kind? WILF bends while DR. COGAN goes to fit the flower in his Their faces close. He grins at her.
You don’t have a lapel, Wilf.
What do you know?
Go for your walk, Wilf.

Other residents and their visitors also taking the air, greeting each other. WILF waves. Some wave back. From a nearby window, the muffled, intermittent sound of “Underneath the Arches” accompanied by piano and trumpet. Four Gilbert and Sullivan singers are playing croquet.
A pound says I'll kick your arse, Nigel.
The way you play, I’m sure you will.  16

WILF continues to stroll. Faintly we hear the sound of a clarinet coming from the SUMMERHOUSE. Sitting inside, OLLY FISHER playing “Who is Sylvia.” WILF pauses, waves to OLLY. OLLY then takes a deep breath and another. He takes a pil from his pill box and puts it under his tongue. WILF obse closely. When his breathing is restored, WILF and OLLY exchange a thumbs up. EXT. FOUNTAIN GARDEN —- DAY NOBBY chatters while overseeing SIMON digging over a bed. WILF strolls toward them from behind.
(calling to him) Morning, Nobby.
(calling back) Morning, Mr. Bond.
Simon, wassup?
All good, mate.
It’s going to be a scorcher.
Global warming.
Or just an English summer, one of the two. By the way, when you have a chance I could use another of the “usual.” NOBBY refuses money that WILF offers him.
No problem. I still have change from the last time. I’11 put it in the “usual” place. NOBBY nods his head to a place off the premises.  17
(continues to walk) And watch out, Nobby, Cissy Robson's been looking for you all morning. Can't think why, I'm so much more attractive. WILF walks on.
(calls out) Says you. (beat, shouts after WILF) How’s the leg?
Which one?

On the terrace, tables and chairs under parasols. Residents reading, TONY and DAVE are playing a game of draughts. REGGIE sits at a table in a shaded corner, writing, preparing his lecture - A BIOGRAPHY OF VERDI and The Telegraph are on the table next to him. CISSY, seated next to REGGIE, listens to her CD while watching TWO LITTLE GIRLS (one of them is ESME) and a BOY playing on the grass. LETITIA, sitting on the other side of the terrace, with her DAUGHTER, chat while watching their kids. WILF approaches, goes to sit next to REGGIE and CISSY. REGGIE glances up and continues writing.
(as he sits) I read somewhere that the average man thinks about sex every seven seconds.
(writing) And do you?  18
(gazing at CISSY as she sits) I wish it was only every seven seconds.
You need to see a psychiatrist.
Male or female? REGGIE continues to write.

(picking up a newspaper on the table, pulls his glasses on, looks at the crossword puzzle) You left a word out. (states the clue - and he gets it, pauses, he studies CISSY, takes his glasses off) When I first saw her, God knows how long ago, I thought she was the most beautiful, sexiest thing I'd ever clapped eyes on. The alarm on REGGIE’S wristwatch sounds. He is about to t CISSY on the arm but WILF stops him with a look.

Cissy, let Reg and me have our way with you now. Go on, bea sport, on the lawn, legs apart, bloomers abandoned. I'll remove my truss. (taps her on the arm with his cane, she removes her headset and looks at WILF) How about it?
Ready. WILF loves it. REGGIE is forced to smile.
What are you laughing at?
Nothing -  19
Why did you interrupt me? Can’t you see I’m listening to us?
To what?
Rigoletto. The quartet. We are so lovely -
Were. (taps his watch) Cissy, the gala committee.
Oh yes, yes - She rises, in a flurry, starts to go.
(to WILF) Royal Opera House, Nineteen- Sixty - whatever it was, Covent Garden. Do you remember, Wilf?
It’s the last time the four of us sang it. We had done it, what, fifty times before that? CISSY comes darting back for her bag.

And thank you Reggie. I’m so relieved you’re safely back from Karachi. She starts to hurry away, but momentarily can’t remember which way to go. Clutching her bag, leaving the CD cover the table, but it falls to the ground.
Why Karachi?
Her father was Indian army.
Yes, yes, yes, so he was. Do you think she's getting worse?

(quietly) Yes.  20 WILF bends down to pick up the CD cover, but ends up sitting on the ground. He looks at the CD cover. REGGIE (CONT’D) (still reading and making notes) I’m glad they’ve reissued it. We might get royalties. WILF tries vainly to get up.
I wish they’d reissue us instead. REGGIE helps him to his feet.

They might have put our photographs on the cover instead of just our names. WILF studies the CD cover. In bold letters against an appropriate background: CLASSIC RECORDINGS - Jean HORTON sings GILDA with Reginald PAGET, Cecily ROBSON, Wilfred BOND in RIGOLETTO

Dizzy heights, those days. (sits) ‘Jean Horton sings Gilda.’ I should have had top billing. Name part, after all. (looks off) I remember the production, the recording sessions, everything, as if it were yesterday yet I can't remember what we had for breakfast this morning-
(quietly) - fucking apricot jam, that’s what you had.

(looks at CD again) Everyone said the quartet had never been better sung. My picture in the Daily Mail with the caption: “Wilfred Bond - A New Star?” Question mark. I was famous for a day. Still, I made a living and that’s all I ever wanted. I’m not like you, Reg. You’re an artist, I’m an artisan —  21
Have you listened to it?
No. Have you?
No, no way, Wilf. No way.
Of course. Clumsy of me. These two old friends share a moment. REGGIE writes again CISSY returns, panicked.
Have you seen my CD case? WILF hands it to her. She rushes away as SIMON walks by.
(to SIMON - a rap line from Tinie Tempah’s "Pass Out”) “I'm born famous I’m sorta’ known”
“If your son doesn’t”
“I bet your daughter knows” WILF and SIMON put their fists in the air. REGGIE makes a face. WILF (CONT’D) Reg, you might as well get used to it. Rap is here to stay.
Why? Rap is not music.
It is to them.  22
CISSY hurries through the Music Room. The Gilbert and Sullivan troop are rehearsing “Flowers that Bloom in the Spring.”

Seated around a table are BOBBY, ANNE LANGLEY, LETITIA an DAPHNE, who takes the minutes. CEDRIC, in a new caftan, i standing and in full flight, waving The Times under BOBBY nose pointing at an interview with a photo of FRANK WHITE CISSY opens the door quietly and comes in.

(to the table) ..-When this came out last week we were assured of our much needed sell out concert and increased donations. Now it’s a bloody disaster. If we can’t make the gala into the hottest ticket in town, this house could collapse about our ears. We could lose it. None of us wants to be turfed out into the street with nowhere to go. (looks up, sees CISSY)
(at the door) I certainly don’t want to be turfed out.
You're late.
Apologies. (nothing from the others; they stare at her) What? What? I apologise for being late, I’m sorry, I -
(throws the paper down on the table) Close the door. Frank White has pulled out. He doesn’t feel up for the Gala.
He’s not well.
Obviously.  23
(at the closed door) And one of our gala highlights. Oh dear! Frank White, such a lovely man.
(tapping the table sharply) This is a disaster.
Who was it who said, 'Old age is not for sissies'?
Next item!
I always remember that because of my name, you see, Cissy, sissies -
(to CISSY) Cissy! If you want to speak, raise your hand! (picks up a financial paper, tosses it to

As of today, pledges from our benefactors have fallen by 60%. The givers aren’t giving. We have to find a replacement for Frank, urgently. CISSY raises her hand. From the next room we faintly hear “Flowers that bloom in the spring, tra-la” etc.
What?
Bette Davis! She was the one who said old age is not- CEDRIC moves toward CISSY. She stops talking, frightened. CEDRIC walks right past her - goes to the door, opens it, walks out. CEDRIC’S VOICE
(singing continues) Shut it! (they stop mid way through Tra-La-La) You will choose a different song immediately. I will have no Tra-La- La at MY gala!  24 CEDRIC storms back into the room.
What about Reggie? La Donna é Mobile?
Good. Cissy ask him.
Reggie is funny about La Donna é Mobile. I don’t think he will.
Your job is to ask him!
Look! They all turn to look.

As DR. COGAN and SIMON wait, the people carrier comes to a halt at the entrance. DR. COGAN helping JEAN to alight. TADEK and SIMON, unload her trunk and many suitcases. In the driveway, a lorry is picking up laundry in sacks. JEAN sees them being loaded. CISSY’S VOICE (barely audible) Heavens above -
DR. COGAN escorts JEAN through the front door. They start to walk through the empty large room. She is unhappy, embattled. JEAN looks up at A LARGE PAINTING of Sir Thomas Beecham.
That's Sir Thomas Beecham. One of Britain’s great conductors. The house is named after him.
I know who Sir Thomas Beecham was, thank you. He inherited a fortune. His grandfather made laxatives -so I’m sure naming this nursing home after him is frighteningly apt.  25
(patiently) It is not a nursing home. It is an exclusive, private retirement home. DR. COGAN opens the second door to the MAIN HALL and JEAN limps through it. They pause at the flowers.
These are to welcome you. I'll have them sent up to your room later. We're very honoured to have you. You have a lovely room. Our largest. In what we call the “BY Wing -
The “B” Wing? Sounds like prison.
(smiles uncertainly) The service lift is being repaired - (indicates with her hand) - but you can take the chair lift, it’ll be easier for you.

(looks at the chair lift at the bottom of the stairs) Take the chair lift? What do I do when I get to the top? Ski down? JEAN follows the rail from the bottom stair to the top. From behind, someone begins to clap. Then more join in. JEAN turns and looks up. She sees RESIDENTS applauding he from the MAIN HALL LANDING. JEAN is at first taken aback but then visibly glows, takes a step into the MAIN HALL, smiles and nods graciously.
Brava!
(joining in) Brava! Brava!
Close up on a sharp crack, a ball goes through a hoop. Not an easy shot. WILF, mallet in one hand, walking stick in the other, watches. Their banter is habitual:  26

(lining up his next shot, turns to WILF) What about (names a part in an opera)? Just in time, REGGIE sees WILF’S foot move his own ball towards the hoop for an easier shot. REGGIE (CONT’D) (off-hand, not taking his eye off his ball) You just moved your ball.
Me? Unthinkable -
I saw you -—
Never-
I clearly just saw you move it - WILF has been watching an attractive female visitor walki by with her husband.
(eyes following the woman) Balls!
Precisely. Wilf, she’s married.
Precisely. (he quotes a phrase from an Opera in Italian) They play on and are enthusiastic about the prospect of performing.  He plays. through. 27
(lining up his shot) We could always do “The Barber,” you, Cissy, and I, for the Gala. That would draw the crowds.
Yes, but what I would love to sing again is Macbeth! It’s been years, and I miss it.
(aiming) I always wanted to sing Wagner. Tristan. Just once. But it never came my way. Too many parts, too little time. (looks at WILF) Stand back. You’re obscuring my line.
You won’t get it through, not from there-
(melodramatic) Oh yes, I will.
(melodramatic) Oh no you won't. The ball hits the hoop but doesn’t go
(walks to a nearby tree) Told you.
You were in the way.
Was not -
Were!
(starts to unzip) Was not!
(looks at WILF behind the tree) What are you doing now?  28

What does it look like I’m doing now? (trying to urinate) Wagner?!! Only bloody foreigners sing Wagner. We're best at the British composers. Rossini, Donizetti, Verdi - (REGGIE smiles; WILF looks down) C'mon! C’mon! CISSY’S VOICE Reggie! Wilf! They turn to see CISSY rushing towards them out of breath and over-excited.
I know who it is, I saw her, I saw her, George was right, it’s a star, but you’1ll never, never, never guess who, never -
(zipping up) Then tell us, we don’t want to be kept in suspense for eternity-
You won't believe this. Still large as life and twice as terrifying. (suddenly still) Oh God! It’s gone! Damnation, what’s her name, begins with G. Soprano, famous -
Famous soprano beginning with G. Mary Garden -
Rita Gorr -
Galli-Curci -
No, no.
Cissy, think. She thinks, brow furrowed.  29
Gilda! Our Gilda!
Oh! G, Gilda, yes, I see, our “Gilda,” Rigoletto. You mean Jean Horton-
Yes! How clever of you! Yes, Jean Horton.
Jean Horton? Here? (he and CISSY look at
You all right, old son? REGGIE is frozen. No response.
If it’s any consolation, Reg, she’s aged terribly. She looks a hundred- Brief, tense silence.
Steady, Reg, steady, NSP, NSP - REGGIE walks away.

It'll be all right, old son, trust me — REGGIE throws down his mallet and marches off towards the house. WILF and CISSY watch him, deeply concerned. INT. DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - DAY DR. COGAN, standing beside a table getting coffee. REGGIE is standing.
(furious) ...that’s why you kept it such a secret. You didn’t want me to know. It’s intolerable. I should have been consulted, Dr. Cogan. I should have been warned.  30
Jean Horton was such a big star. She didn’t want media attention. Nor did we -
She didn’t want? Always, always, always what she wants - nothing changes.
(gently) It had nothing to do with you, Reginald. It was simply at her request.
She did know that I live here?
Yes.

She knew. (Beat) It's been so calm here. So agreeable. (DR. COGAN listens sympathetically as REGGIE rails on) Do you know what I wanted? I wanted a dignified senility. I scrimped and saved - repaired my own clothes, had only one glass of red wine a day. One! My only indulgence was to buy from time to time my favourite cologne. And why? So that I could afford without charity a decent room of my own in this house. And now she’s here. (moving toward the door) I shall have to find somewhere else to live.
Reginald, I’m sure she -
You don’t know her! REGGIE opens the door to leave.
Aren’t you giving a talk to the school children tomorrow?  31
(resigned, as he’s leaving) Dear God -
Your talks are so valuable, Reggie. These children have never been to an opera -
Close on a television - OTELLO. Three or four RESIDENTS, including NORMA, are watching, among them, ANNE LANGLEY.
(gesturing to TV) Why can’t we find Otello’s like that today - they don’t exist.
Desdemona sounds nice.
That’s such an easy part. They continue their critique of the performances. A burst of laughter from the other side of the room as WI slaps down a card theatrically.
Canasta! I win!
You cheated! Reveal at a corner of the room, WILF sits with REGINA, violin, LOTTE and MARION. DR. COGAN enters the room and looks around.
Wilf, have you seen Reginald?
He turned in early. But he’s fine. Tough as a monkey’s tit, is Reggie.
(turns toward the terrace) Who’s smoking?
I suspect it’s George and Harry.  32 The French doors are open, through which the backs of GEO and HARRY can be seen.
I don’t know how many times I’ve told them, smoking kills!
For god’s sake, doc, leave ‘em be. George is seventy-six and Harry's nearly eighty. What the hell’s it matter?
(smiles ) You're a bad influence, Wilfred. DR. COGAN shakes her head, turns and walks away as WILF watches her.
Give us a wiggle- (DR. COGAN continues walking) Do that again.
I didn’t give you the first one.
If I live another five years, I'll have her. I just need time.  33
JEAN, with difficulty, puts a record player next to the flowers on a table. She takes the cord in hand, looking f an outlet.
Dim light. DR. COGAN comes along the corridor, sees a light under a door, knocks gently and opens the door.

JEAN is kneeling, trying to fit the plug of the record player into a socket on the skirting board. She puts on h glasses. In the suitcase beside her, a pile of LPs - we barely make out the titles - JEAN HORTON’S GREATEST ARIAS and THE BEST OF JEAN HORTON, others. She hears the knock, hurriedly closes the suitcase, takes off her glasses, tries to rise, but can’t. She winces in pain as DR COGAN looks in.
(a little alarmed, hesitant to help) Are you all right? (MORE )
(a withering stare from JEAN; gently) Isn't this room lovely?
The bed takes up half the room.
You've had a long day. You might want to retire early.
I have not yet entered second childhood so please don’t talk to me as though I have. Just leave me be. And I will take my meals in my room. A brief pause.
We don’t usually serve the residents in their rooms.
You do, I presume, when the resident is not feeling well. I’m not feeling well. DR COGAN hesitates, uncertain as whether or not to offer JEAN a helping hand. She decides against it.
I hope you feel better soon. DR. COGAN turns and walks out. JEAN struggles to get up and finally sits by the window, exhausted.
DR. COGAN comes to a door. No light showing. On the door, a small brass plaque of the type used on dressing room doors with the name:
She wants to knock but hesitates, decides against it and continues on her way.
REGGIE, a silhouette, stands on the terrace of his room, gazing at a lighted window in the “B” Wing. He can just m out JEAN seated in a chair.  From REGGIE, we move on to LEO in his room.

The Gilbert and Sullivan troop You, Sir, We Much Regret” with One of the four turns the page FELICITY is irritated. Through 35 playing “The Swan” on his cello are rehearsing “So Please FELICITY at the piano. of the score too soon. the window we see NOBBY deadheading roses while SIMON rakes. EXT./INT. WILF’S WINDOW & ROOM — MORNING The music continues over the following scenes. Above the COMMON ROOM, where the four Gilbert and Sullivan singers are rehearsing, the window is flung open and WILF stands greeting the morning air. He goes from breathing deeply to vocalising. CISSY’S VOICE Yoo-hoo! He sees CISSY leaning out her window. He follows her gaze down towards NOBBY and SIMON. NOBBY looks up to see CISSY at him, leaning forward, allowing her window, gazing down at her cleavage to show. She waves alluringly just as WILF'S VOICE, doing scales, comp with the Gilbert and Sullivan singers. NOBBY takes a break from the roses. He removes his shirt and wipes his forehead as he flexes, exciting CISSY.

INT. JEAN'S ROOM —- MORNING JEAN, asleep in the chair by the window, an LP jacket sitting in her lap. She is woken with a start by the cacophony of singing and vocalising. Wearily, she raises her eyes to heaven. EXT. WILF’S WINDOW Looking down, WILF sees CISSY, a robe over her bathing suit, being coquettish with NOBBY and SIMON on her way to the swimming pool building.  36
Those roses are so beautiful. What are they called, Nobby?
They're Elizabeth of Glamis, Miss Robson, named after the late Queen Mother. And those are Iceberg.
Named after Jean Horton, I suppose. She knows she’s made a joke. She puts a finger to her lip and runs off. NOBBY smiles.
(calling to NOBBY) Nobby - 1. Wilf - Nil!

Close on Newspapers being dropped on tables or chairs as RESIDENTS eat. They vary, depending on the preference of reader. WILF and LEO at their table. The seat next to WIL (REGGIE'S) is empty. WILF and SIMON exchange nods as SIMO drops The Telegraph on the seat. His Full English breakfa hardly touched. WILF takes the paper and finds the sports page.
(with HARRY, at their table) Is Reggie coming or not? This really is very unfair.
It’s all yours, boys - As WILF leaves, GEORGE immediately starts to move their plates as CEDRIC smirks at his table.
WILF taps lightly on REGGIE'S door. No answer. He cracks the door open, looks and walks in. He sees no one there. WILF leaves and closes the door. Walks away.
WILF descends the staircase. He enters the COMMON ROOM wh DAVE is playing BACH’S FUGUE IN D MINOR on the piano. WIL walks to the FITNESS ROOM, opens the door, CEDRIC is havi his nails done.
Excuse me, this room is occupied!
(as he closes the door) Don’t do your toes the same color, Cedric, it’s considered gauche. WILF (CONT’D) Good Morning, Dr. C. Have you seen Reggie?

Yes, he asked if he could use the computer. He’s in my office. INT. ENTRANCE HALL - OUTSIDE DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - MORNING WILF knocks and opens the door. He sees REGGIE inside at the computer. INT. DR. COGAN’S OFFICE - MORNING
Reggie. You okay?
I don’t wish to be disturbed. I’m working.
Can I get you a cup of cof--
I’m preparing my talk. Please close the door when you leave. WILF looks at REGGIE then walks out, closing the door. ON THE COMPUTER SCREEN: Rap information.

On a table, a tray with half a glass of juice. JEAN is holding a cup of coffee while laying out her clothes for the day. Most of the suitcases remain unopened.  38 Disconcerted, she drops a garment back into an opened portmanteau. JEAN moves to the dressing-table, sits, gazi at herself in the mirror. She holds up different pieces o jewelry. A knock on the door.
Who? CISSY’S VOICE A friend.
(suspicious) Come. CISSY enters. JEAN stares at her blankly.
(as to a child) It’s me, Jean. Cissy. Cicely Robson.
Why does everybody here treat me like a half-wit? (goes back to brushing her hair; off-hand) I know who you are. Where's Reggie?
It's lovely to see you here, Jean. I've been telling everyone, you still look like a young girl -
(checks her profile in the mirror) I don’t feel it. I'm very slow. I'm on a waiting-list for a new hip.
You have such beautiful jewelry. JEAN starts to put a necklace on.
Oh, do let me, Jean. You remember how you used to like me to give your make-up the once over before you went on? (clips the necklace, and picks out a pair of earrings) (MORE)
We'll have you looking as you always did, youthful and whining - (corrects herself quickly) Shining. Youthful and shining - In the mirror JEAN watches CISSY.
(a trace of an affectionate smile) You certainly haven't changed. I asked you where Reggie is. JEAN, through the window, sees a COACH pulling up. School children start to get out.
Who are those children?
(looking) Oh, Reggie must be giving one of his talks today. (noticing the tray with orange juice) Did they serve you breakfast in your room?
Of course they did.
CISSY and JEAN walk from JEAN’S ROOM.

...-what with people being sent away if they're too ill or go completely doolally, of course one gets depressed from time to time - I mean, I’ve woken up with the black dog on my shoulder a couple of times - but it never lasts for long. How could it? You'll see, we all look after each other and that's very cheering - JEAN and CISSY walk on. JEAN and CISSY are near the bottom of the stairs. BOBBY, the background, waits.
...there's so much to enjoy here. People coming and going -  40
(hissing) Cissy!
(continuing) - new faces, old friends, families with their children, new interests - From behind a door the sound of salsa music.
What's that awful noise?
Oh, I’m in this class. CISSY opens the double doors.
SHERYL, is teaching salsa to a group of residents who try to follow her movements.
Cissy! You're missing class, come on in.
(game as ever) Oh, shall we, Jean?

(to herself) This is not a retirement home, this is a madhouse. CISSY goes in and does some steps. JEAN gives her a withering look and starts to walk on. CISSY starts out after her as BOBBY intercepts her, handing her a note.
(hissing) Birthday Benefit Gala. Emergency. Top secret. He scuttles off. CISSY puts on glasses, reads the note as catches up with JEAN.
Didn't that used to be Bobby Swanson?  41
(puzzled by the note) Yes -
He didn't seem to recognise me. How odd.
His sight isn't what it was. CISSY and JEAN walk on.
Such an_intense little man. He always looks as though he's SPY. ing for a foreign power. What does the note say?
Birthday Benefit Gala. Emergency. Top Secret.
Birthday benefit gala? Whose birthday? Mine isn't until the 6th of January?
(re-reading the note, puzzled) No, no, not yours, Jean, Giuseppe Verdi's. There's a Benefit Gala. Everyone's expected to perform to save our Beecham House-
What do you mean, perform?
They walk toward the SMALL MUSIC ROOM.
We have to do what we do, Jean.
At our age? Ridiculous!
Everyone does something.
I won't sing at Verdi's gala or anyone else’s. And that's final.
I was listening to our Rigoletto this morning. We were all so good, especially your Gilda.  42
(taking the compliment) I never got less than twelve curtain calls. (looking at the note) What’s the emergency?
(shows JEAN the note) I don't know. He's written 'No one'. What can it mean?
Please, I want to find Reggie. They enter the SMALL MUSIC ROOM.
He’s right here. (starts for the door)
(panics, whispers) No - Wait. Cissy. No!

We are on the faces of the school children. They have bee asked a question by REGGIE, and are shy, or reluctant to answer. They are from a variety of ethnic backgrounds. So surreptitiously fiddle with their mobile phones. REGGIE stands before them. A nearby upright piano against the wall. In the back we see DR. COGAN sitting with OCTAVIA in her wheelchair.
Come on, don’t be shy - Eventually, A GIRL puts her hand up.
Lady Gaga -
Lady Gaga, sounds like someone I know - From the group, A MALE TEENAGER, hip-hop-ish, JOEY, looki at his mobile phone -
So what about you?
(puts his phone away, not making eye contact) (MORE)
Lady Gaga is pop, we like hip- hop, period.
Is hip hop like rap?
Kinda man, but it’s different.
(looking at JOEY) Help me out here, tell me what’s rap? At the door, in the SMALL MUSIC ROOM, CISSY starts to ope it. JEAN, consternated, holds her back.
(whispering) Wait. Don’t. Wait, wait. CISSY has already cracked the door open a bit. Out of sig they listen. JEAN doesn’t know whether to stay or leave.
Show him! SCHOOL CHILDREN start to laugh.
Spit it!
Drop a verse, man.
(looking off) Raps from the street while you're in class, so all you teachers can kiss my ass - SCHOOL CHILDREN laugh.
Go on! Continue!
Continue what?
What you're feeling. Now, they share a look - his friends push him to stand up
(busts out) What you wanna know? ‘bout how I grow to be a bad ‘ting? (MORE)

Or the way that my brain sings When I think of my birth What you wanna know? You wanna know hate crime? Or life rhymes? Or the way that the po-po Makes my heart go When their jake tops wail by? (mimes a siren) Ne-nah ne-nah ne-nah (class laughs, JOEY is getting into this) What you wanna know? You wanna know how life down my endz Means we aint no politicians friend We’re the excuse, we're the left-— outs, we're the done What you wanna know? Pause as they eye each other.
What does “po-po” mean?
Cops.
And jake tops?
Cops.
Anybody else?
(suddenly free-styles)

That’s opera! Originally people just like yourselves went to see Opera. But then the rich came along and made it something that it’s not. So what is it then? Someone said, ‘Opera is when a guy is stabbed in the back and while he’s bleeding, he sings.' (some school children laugh; ) Rap is when a guy gets stabbed in the back and while he’s bleeding, he talks - rhythmically and emotionally, but because rap is spoken the emotion is held in check. It’s on one note. (MORE)
‘Why should we listen to some old fart, giving us shit about his art.’ In Opera, however, we sing our feelings to the rise and fall of the music. The song sets our emotions free. OPERA

head_text.subj: THEN, IS AN OUTPOURING OF ALL
THE EMOTIONS THAT ALL OF US

text: CARRY INSIDE. And...it’s performed by athletes! Oh yes! (he points to three kids) Can you stand up? You three - you’re fit young men. Football players? They nod.

Well, we have athletes here as well. Let me introduce you to the wonderful Octavia. She’1ll be joining us for this next part. (points to the rappers) You gentlemen, stand up, pick a note, sing it, and hold it for as long as you can and as loudly as you can. Octavia, will do the same. Ready? One..two..three..Go! The three school children and OCTAVIA sing their notes. T peter out at around ten seconds. OCTAVIA keeps going on a When she finally stops -
(smiles) I’m seventy-nine. What’s your excuse? When I was your age, I had the highest recorded C note. THE SCHOOL CHILDREN laugh and applaud.

What you’ve witnessed is the strength and athleticism of an Opera singer. The people who live here have the superhuman effort it takes to deliver the goods, to breathe, yes, to hold a note — (gestures to OCTAVIA) - like the one Octavia just sang - (distracted by the door opening a crack; irritated) Who is that? CISSY widens the door to include her and JEAN. Smiles.
It’s us!  46 As some kids turn to the door, REGGIE sees JEAN, bridles, and looks away.

The heroines, sopranos - those are the ladies with the highest voices - they sing a repetitive theme that’s in all opera. Infidelity. Infidelity. Infidelity. As the Duke sings in Rigoletto - REGGIE looks again at the door. It’s empty. He stares at
(disconcerted) ‘La donna é mobile qual plumo al vento’. Women are as fickle as a feather in the wind.’
WILF is playing draughts with GEORGE, while HARRY watches. WILF sees REGGIE on the lawn walk by.
Reggie? (REGGIE doesn’t answer ) Reggie? How did the talk go? REGGIE keeps walking. WILF watches him and then rises.
WILF walks in, goes to a costume and takes out a bottle o Whiskey from a pocket. From another pocket, he takes out plastic cups.
WILF walks over a bridge towards the woods.
REGGIE, alone, staring out into the landscape, observing a deer. WILF’S VOICE (whispering) ‘Tis I. REGGIE half turns as WILF joins him.  47
(admiring the deer) That’s a beauty.
I don’t want to talk.
Of course not.
I really can do without this at my time of life.
(pause) Do you want me to go?
(quietly) No. WILF produces the whiskey and two plastic cups.
(a ritual) Shall we? REGGIE observes, but says nothing.
JEAN and CISSY are strolling. Now and then CISSY steals a glance at JEAN, monitoring her sadness.
Don't worry darling, I know where the boys are. They walk.

Shall we sit for a moment? (gestures to a bench by the rose bed; they sit, she looks around) A few residents with visitors, among them OLLY slowly bouncing his GRANDDAUGHTER, DAISY, on his shoulders. JEAN CISSY catch the tail end of OLLY’S pony-ride. OLLY begins put her down.
No Grandpa! One more! OLLY struggles to put her back on his shoulders.  47.
Oh, look, there's Olly with his grandchildren. (calling) Daisy, sweetheart! OLLY gently puts DAISY on the ground, who runs over and gives CISSY a big hug.  48

Which hand? CISSY has taken a sweet from her pocket and holds her han behind her back. DAISY chooses a hand and CISSY gives her treat. The parents of the child wave to CISSY and then be to DAISY, who runs back.
Bye-bye, Cissy - CISSY smiles and waves.
How lovely it is to have visitors, like family. Will you have visitors, Jean? No response.
(trying to get out of her funk) At least the garden is a joy.

(eyes and attention on NOBBY, who is now walking nearby) Yes, and the woods are lovely too. You know Jean, for someone like me, who never married, never had children, whose nearest and dearest are long departed, this place is a God-send, a blessing, like a fairground ablaze with fairy lights - (lost for a moment; then) The bluebells were quite glorious this year. But they're finished now.
Like us.
And you should have seen the polyanthus and forget-me-nots. I don't expect you get them in Karachi. JEAN flicks her a sideways glance, as CISSY puts a sweet mouth. She offers one to JEAN.
The yellow ones are my favourite.  49
REGGIE and WILF are sitting inside holding plastic cups containing whiskey. They have been drinking for awhile. REGGIE is in the process of refilling his.
So, come on, old son, break into song. REGGIE smiles. He’s been talking about aging.

.--and in that way, we’re not the same. I’m not like you, Wilf. I positively liked getting old. Physical decay has seemed natural and inescapable. I think I can say I've welcomed the inevitable cheerfully. I’ve made the transition from opera star to old fart with aplomb (beat) Then Jean arrives...
I remember thinking when you two got married...she was much more ambitious than you-
Of course she was. She was more ambitious than all of us.
-if I know anything about it.
What can you know about it?  50
I was your best man, Reggie.
Yes, and then you were married to the same woman for thirty thousand years. Call me old fashioned but did she know how often you were unfaithful to her?

You say some very harsh things, Reg. (gets up, a little unsteady. ) I think I’1l have myself a widdle. (looks around for the right tree, a little tipsy) You're right, Reg. I hate growing old. Hate every bloody moment of it. If it's not your prostate, it's piles. And then it's peeing five times a night. If you’re lucky. WILF steps off the Summer House and stumbles to a nearby tree. He unzips and begins to pee when he catches a glimpse of CISSY and JEAN walking nearby and sees that they have spotted him. WILF (CONT’D) (shouts as he is peeing) You may want to avert your gaze, ladies. This may take a while. A wise man goes when he can, girls. A fool goes when he must. He looks up to see REGGIE still in the Summer House, standing at the edge, wanting to flee.
Easy, Reg, easy- By this time, CISSY and JEAN are near enough for JEAN to see REGGIE as he indelicately climbs down from the Summer House, takes a few steps, his back to them.  51
(as they approach) Look! Here's Jean in all her glory.
Yes, yes, I know. How are the mighty fallen.
(glances at REGGIE as he goes to kiss JEAN on both cheeks) Tactless as ever. You haven't changed a jot.
(admiring JEAN) Didn't I say so? Didn't I say she still looks like a young girl? JEAN takes a step towards REGGIE.

Reggie, don’t I get a kiss? (he keeps his back to her) Reg? (takes a step closer) I apologise for hurting you. Please be kind to me. We were different people then. There. I've rehearsed saying that for the past week. Brief silence. He registers what she’s saying, looks away. He starts
He's upset because he wasn't warned that you were coming.
I’m not upset - to walk.
Reg. It’s the first time we've seen each other in God knows how many years.
Ninety-seven.  52
Has it been as long as that? How time flies. (thinks a second) Oh, you’re joking.
What's wrong with Bobby? He nods towards the garden.

BOBBY, a little distance off, stands gesticulating. He taps his watch, makes imploring gestures, taps his watch again, beckons. Now, exasperated, he takes a few steps as if walking away, then returns, a little closer now, and starts gesticulating all over again. WILF’S VOICE I think he’s trying to tell us something. (calling) Bobby, give us a clue, for God's sake. Film, book or play?
Cissy! All their eyes on BOBBY.
It's for you, Cissy.
(a shouted whisper) The note!
(calling) I couldn't read your handwriting!
Meeting! Now!
(remembering) Oh yes, the emergency - She hurries off towards BOBBY.
I wonder what that’s all about.  53 JEAN looks round and doesn’t see REGGIE.
Where’s Reg?
(looks down the path) There he is.
(starts down the path, calls out) Reg! Why does he treat me like this? It's not fair. As if I haven't suffered enough.
(calling out to her) NSP, Jean, NSP.
(turns her head) And what, for God's sake, does that mean?
It’s one of our rules. In fact, it’s our motto. NSP. No Self Pity. She turns and walks towards REGGIE.
REGGIE walking.

Walking towards the Church, carrying their instruments, a procession of the string quartet, BILL, lst violin, REGIN 2nd violin, FRED, viola, and LEO, cello. We can’t make ou the words, but there seems to be a disagreement between them. SIMON and ANGELIQUE carry music stands. JEAN making her way down the path, looking this way and that. The sound of the first movement, Allegro con spirit of Haydn’s 'Sunrise' Quartet begins as she passes.
The music faintly behind her, JEAN pauses, peers about. A the end of the path, is a church. JEAN takes a few steps towards it, looks more closely and sees the door is ajar.  54
She looks inside, goes in, looking about. At the other en she sees REGGIE silhouetted behind a lattice screen.
Reggie? May I join you?
(vehement ) No, you may not.
I've walked miles to find you, Reggie.
Just leave me in peace, Jean -
I just want to - She starts to advance.
For Christ's sake, just leave me in peace! Leave! Leave!
(shocked) Reggie!

I said leave! Emotional, about to leave, doesn’t. She sits at the edge a pew. From afar, the strains of the Haydn quartet. REGGIE finally walks over to her, stands a short distance away. After a long pause, he relents, and hands her a spotless white handkerchief. She dabs at her eyes and nos
(smelling the handkerchief) Pino Silvestre. I didn't know you could still buy it. (dabs her nose, then aware of him gazing at her) What?
I can't ever remember you crying.
I didn’t know you’d become religious.  55
I haven't. I was simply trying to avoid you.
(handkerchief to her nose) My mother taught me never to let others see I was hurt.
Your mother knew all about hiding her feelings. It was easy for her. She didn't have any.
Don't be unkind about her.

I liked your father. When he heard that you'd left me, he telephoned and said, ‘Sorry, old chap, but count your blessings. I'm still married to her mother.’ REGGIE moves towards the door. Brief pause.
I apologise for hurting you. Please be kind to me. We were different people then. There. I've been rehearsing saying that for the past week.
(close to the door) You've said it before. You're repeating yourself.
(thinks ) Oh God. (brief silence) Why do we have to grow old?
Because that’s what people do. A brief silence.
What I did was unforgiveable - but I was young and foolish. (he nods, moves closer to the door) Reggie, we have to come to some arrangement. (MORE)
We can't keep avoiding each other or, worse, bickering like children every time we meet -
(at door, interrupting) Jean, I don't want to talk about it. I don’t want to re-live ancient history. You're here. I'm here. Trapped. That's all there is to it. Silence but for the distant music.
What are we going to do? He broods for a moment. Then:

I was thinking you did. JEAN ignores WILF, looks at REGGIE who has just opened hi gift, a jar of lime marmalade and looks up at JEAN. He is moved. Their eyes meet.  87 From somewhere, the sound of a violin playing Massenet’s Meditation from Thais, to the accompaniment of a harp. There is an awkward silence.
(looks at others) Is that it?
(confused) Yes. WILF rises awkwardly from his perch and moves to the door
(at door) Thanks for the signed CD. Do you mind if we put them on eBay? Another awkward pause. WILF and REGGIE exchange shared lo CISSY, still seated on the bed, looks in her purse.
(rises) Thank you for coming. CISSY, rises, confused, takes out earphones attempts to untangle them.
C’mon Cissy. CISSY goes toward WILF. REGGIE stands by his chair.
(still untangling earphones ) Have you changed your mind about the gala?
(emphatic) No.
(a slow burn) Of course you haven’t. Why should you? It’s only to celebrate and honour the birthday of one of the greatest composers for the human voice who has ever lived.
You must understand that I was somebody once -  88
(still untangling) I thought I was somebody now -
But to be honest, I shone the brightest in the firmament. WILF murmurs a Gaelic curse. JEAN realizes she’s gone too far.
I cannot insult the memory of who I once was.

(explodes ) “The memory?” What do you mean “the memory?” Whose “memory?” Your fans? They’re dead. They’re all dead! Either that or they’re living here and soon will be. REGGIE holds a hand out to stop WILF.
For Christ sake Jean, all you've ever done is to rely on external affirmation. And look what it cost you. Just fucking do it!
What you refuse to understand is that I’m a different person today.

No, you’re not. Nor are we. We've aged, that’s all. And it happened so fast, we didn’t have time to change. In spirit, I’m the same lovely lad I always was. I just happen to be trapped in a cage made of rusty iron bars, with, thank the lord, an undiminished level of testosterone.
I simply can’t. (all eyes on her; barely audible) My gift deserted me.
It deserted us, too, Jean. It’s called life.  89
(looks at REGGIE) Yes. Shit happens.
Oh my darling, ageing is not for sissies.
No. Her eyes fall on REGGIE’s. All smile.
Let go, Jean, let go. There’s no harm. Who knows - we might even enjoy it. We’re artists aren’t we? And we're meant to celebrate life. What else were we doing for all those years?
Oh Christ, Reggie. Are you telling me to go out and smell the roses?
Oh - the roses are long gone. But the chrysanthemums are extraordinary. It breaks the tension.
Please, Jean. If you say yes, Cedric will give us the star spot instead of Anne Langley.
(suddenly alert) Anne Langley? Here at Beecham house? I thought they’d committed her.
She wanted to sing Violetta. She was a very fine Violetta.
Oh please, Cissy, Violetta is supposed to be dying of tuberculosis. Anne Langley looked as if she was singing Falstaff and she sounded like a cat hang gliding.
Well, she’s singing Tosca now. We would have the Finale, Jean!  90
Tosca?
You were the most brilliant Tosca ever, Jean. The last time I heard her Tosca, her vibrato sounded like it was waving at us.
Not waving, but drowning.
Is that a yes?

Chatter. CISSY and WILF at their table. Sudden silence, then excited murmurs. Entering the dining room, JEAN on REGGIE’S arm making a royal entrance. They pass ANNE LANGLEY. JEAN gives her a gracious smile, a Queen Motherly wave. ANNE LANGLEY stares back, she gets up and marches out of the dining room. JEAN and REGGIE reach the table.  91 As JEAN sits - One at a time, then joining all together, SIX RESIDENTS spread throughout the room start singing “Happy Birthday, EVA and MARTA bring a lit Birthday cake towards OCTAVIA i her wheel chair.

Pull yourself together, Anne. What does it matter when you sing?
I was told I had the finale. I've been second fiddle to Jean Horton for God knows how many years. (MORE)
And I only ever got the parts she turned down. In my sleep I'm a far better singer than she is and she’s - she’s so - so anorexic. Damn her! It’s not fair! She only sings from the chest. Damn her!
We hear music from Rigoletto from inside the church.
The STRING QUARTET, TONY ROSE, LETITIA with FELICITY turning pages, finish the music. Seated are REGGIE, WILF, CISSY and JEAN. All eyes on JEAN
(quietly) I think we have to cut down the length. I don’t think I can get my breathing back. I’m not sure about the top notes. They nod. They knew her. They know her work ethic.

RESIDENTS being made up by DWAYNE, ANGELIQUE, MARTA, TRACY, and SHERYL. Chatter and excitement, occasional laughter.
The audience continues to settle in. DR. COGAN greets some of the visitors.
REGGIE and WILF are putting the final touches to their Brindisi attire: hair, makeup, etc. behind the screens.

...and then I’1ll say that the quartet from Rigoletto is not only one of Verdi's masterpieces, but also one of the great milestones in the history of opera. And then I shall introduce each of us in turn -

(sitting at a mirror in her dressing gown, doing makeup and hair, etc.) I will enter last. WILF raises his eyes to heaven. CIssy, dressed for the Brindisi and holding articles of makeup is on her way out.
Cissy, where are you going? You have to help me with my gown.
Of course I will Jean. I’m just going to do Anne Langley’s makeup.
You'll need a lot of makeup for that face.
The RESIDENTS, including CISSY, REGGIE and WILF, filing on to the stage and taking their places. BOBBY supervising. CEDRIC peers into the crowd from behind the curtains.
(to BOBBY) ...and that’s the critic from The Times.
DR. COGAN goes to the front and faces the audience.

Ladies and gentlemen- (a hush) Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Beecham House and our annual Gala in honour of Giuseppe Verdi. And today, we celebrate his hundredth birthday. First, I would like to express our debt of gratitude to the amazing Mr. Cedric Livingstone for organising the event. Applause. CEDRIC makes his entrance to his seat and acknowledges the applause graciously.
BOBBY, in white tie and tails, peeping through the curtai at the audience.
Thank you, thank you, ladies and entlemen. And let me just say, in all modesty, great artists need a great director - Applause. CEDRIC milks it, and then sits.

This year, in aid of our rebuilding programme, you have all responded so generously and we thank you for that with all our hearts. And, I, too, would like to thank all those taking part in the Gala itself. The preparations and rehearsals have kept everyone busy and excited for the past few months.  97

I, and all my staff, feel highly privileged to have in our care such talented people, gifted musicians who seem to find renewed energy when they anticipate performing before an audience. It keeps them young.
Sympathetic laughter and applause.

And just let me say something else on behalf of everyone working in Beecham House. We owe those in our charge an enormous debt. They inspire us. Yes, their love of life is infectious and gives us all faith in the future. I mean that. Now. I know many of you are eagerly awaiting our star turn this evening who has proved such an attraction but about whom I will say no more. Applause and murmurs.

Thank you and I hope you have - I’m sure you will have an enjoyable afternoon. She takes her seat as LETITIA and FELICITY enter. CEDRIC ostentatiously starts the applause. LETITIA sits at the piano, FELICITY beside her to turn the pages. The audience begin to settle.
BOBBY, in the wings through the curtains, turns, makes a gesture for the RESIDENTS (including REGGIE, WILF and CISSY) to be still, then a nod.

98 The lights dim. Murmur of anticipation. After a moment the curtains open and the RESIDENTS are revealed, made- up and glowing. Wild applause. BOBBY holds up his hands. Silence. BOBBY gives LETITIA the cue and she starts the introduction to the Brindisi. The residents begin to sing with great enthusiasm.
JEAN, sitting at her mirror. The sound of applause. CISSY bursts in.
Oh, it’s so exciting. They loved the Brindisi.
You’ve kept me waiting. Please help me with my dress.
Instantly. REGGIE and WILF pop in on the way to their room —
Who’s on next?
Anne Langley.

In full swing, LOTTE, NORMA and MARION perform the last chorus of Three Little Maids from School. They wear makeshift kimonos and flutter their fans expertly. The audience are enchanted and applaud wildly.

Jean, I have a confession to make. I think I ought to tell you I hada one-night stand with Roberto D’Angelo, the same week you did.
(amused and surprised) Not you, too, Cissy? What a busy boy he must have been.
Yes and very potent. They smile at each other. CISSY is doing up the hooks on back of JEAN’S dress. After a moment -
How long were you married to Reggie?
Not for very long.
How long?
Exactly nine hours. CISSY finishes JEAN’S hooks and starts to put on her own dress.
Nine hours. How long did you know each other?
Before we were married, we had been, how shall I put it, passionate, if you know what I mean?  102
(wistfully) Oh, I do, I do.
After about a year, he got down on his knees and asked me to marry him. He was very old-fashioned, you know.
He still is.

Yes, he is. So I agreed and a date was fixed. But then we had to change it because I got a job at La Scala. And there I met- I met - She hesitates. Gilbert and Sullivan enter the Common Room, exhilarated.
Go on, go on, I’m breathless, who was it?
No names, no arias. It was nothing serious- just- just one night - with an Italian tenor.
Just one night?

Two. They never take no for an answer. Anyway, Reggie and I were eventually married at three o’clock on a Sunday afternoon in May. My father gave us a suite at the Savoy Hotel. We were to spend the night there and then go to Paris the next morning for our honeymoon. We had a champagne supper. Scrambled eggs, toast and lime marmalade. And then I blurted it out. I told him I'd been unfaithful when I sang at La Scala.
(shocked) You didn’t!
I did.
Why? Why did you tell him?  103
I don’t know. I just did. I felt the need to be honest.
That’s always a mistake.
Reggie demanded to know why I didn’t cancel the wedding. He was very angry... She breaks off.
And he walked out.
No, he ran.
But he was heartbroken, Jean, by your confession, because you'd been unfaithful - After a moment, JEAN nods, wearily, resigned.
Yes, yes, I know that now. I was young and impetuous and driven. (beat - lost in thought) I was afraid of us. I had my career.
That’s why you cheated?  104
No. That's why I told him. (beat) And that was the mistake of my life. And now it’s too late.
You still have your future.
I don’t think there’s a lot of it - there just isn’t. It’s all been.
GEORGE, HARRY, TONY and DAVE finish “Underneath the Arches” to great applause. They bow, look at CEDRIC who is not applauding. They wave their hands to encourage him to clap. He does so. Limply.
Encore! Encore!
I thought you’d never ask - CEDRIC gives them a vulgar V sign as they go into ‘RUN RABBIT RUN’.
JEAN is now doing up the hooks on CISSY’S dress. JEAN struggles with CISSY’S hooks.
God, this is too tight for you, Cissy, I can’t fasten it-
(becomes agitated) But I altered it, I altered it- A knock on the door and SIMON puts his head round.
It’s getting near, ladies - (calling) Did you hear that, gents, it’s getting near?
Thank you, Simon. SIMON goes. JEAN still struggling. CISSY, more agitated.  105
I altered it. Try, Jean, do try-
I am trying, I can’t fasten it-
Stop, stop! I’1l take it off, I‘ll let it out a bit more. (takes off her costume) Where’s the scissors? She starts wandering aimlessly.
Cissy, where are you going?
Home. Didn't I tell you? I’m going home -— CISSY’S eyes have a vacant look.
What are you talking about? CISSY starts to leave the dressing area and heads into the COMMON ROOM.
Well, I’m off. Goodbye. JEAN hobbles after her.
(calls out) Crisis! WILF and REGGIE, in various stages of formal dress, follow CISSY and JEAN. CISSY sees them.
Oh! How awful, I nearly went without saying goodbye. Goodbye, Wilfred, Reginald. Wish me bon voyage. CISSY starts to hurriedly walk through the COMMON ROOM toward the French doors.
For God’s sake, don’t let them see her in this state - REGGIE moves fast after her.  106

To the sound of the string quartet playing the Adagio, RE chases after CISSY. GEORGE and HARRY watch bewildered as head back to the dressing area. CISSY makes for the French doors as REGGIE reaches her, panting.
Cissy, you’re not to leave. It's Verdi’s birthday gala. Now. (CISSY stares at him) We're doing the Quartet from Rigoletto. The Quartet, Cissy-
I do hope it goes well. Goodbye- (suddenly stops, looks past REGGIE) Isn’t that Jean Horton? I thought she wouldn't sing anymore- REGGIE turns to see JEAN and WILF approaching.
She’s done for.
(with some severity) Cissy, pull yourself together. CISSY stares blankly at her; JEAN grips her hands.
Mother and father are waiting for me.
You're not going anywhere, you’re staying here, with your fellow artists. With your friends, Cissy.
Friends who love you, Cissy. We love you, Cissy! (nothing from CISSY) What's the Hindi for love? (loudly) I adore you, Cissy. Don’t run out on me.  107
Cissy, your ship doesn’t sail for two weeks. A faint, flickering response from CISSY.
Doesn’t it? (suddenly alarmed) What time is it?
Late. You have work to do on your dress. An uneasy pause. Then, in a rush:

Yes, yes, yes. (WILF takes her by the hand, starts to lead her back) It's always the little things that upset one, it’ll fit, I know it'll fit- REGGIE gives JEAN his arm as they, too, start to go back.
(a sigh of relief) That was a close run thing. Well done, Jean.
I had a great deal of experience with my mother. Only she used to become violent.
The quartet is coming to the end of the third movement.
Back in the dressing area CISSY wriggles into her costume.
Let’s try again- JEAN starts to do her up. WILF is in the midst of stuffing a second pair of socks into the front of his pants.  108
(to the girls) How’s that? Am I a fine figure of a man or am I not? REGGIE’S VOICE I have to say I find it very distasteful. The girls ignore WILF.
(to JEAN) Well? JEAN manages to fasten the dress.
Just.
Thank God for that.

Well? With one finger from each hand pointing in the direction his crotch. WILF (CONT’D) Well? No_one answers. As they continue getting. ready WILF walks back into his dressing area, removing the socks, shaking his head. WILF (CONT’D) It was just a joke.

The string quartet finish the third movement. JOEY, seate near CEDRIC, starts to applaud. CEDRIC instinctively grab JOEY'S arm to stop him. JOEY aggressively whips his hand away. The string quartet begins the last movement.
REGGIE is looking at his score when SIMON pokes his head around the screen.
Places, ladies. (a little louder) Places, gentlemen.
Thank you, Simon. REGGIE gets up, taking CISSY with him. They walk toward t backstage area.  109
The string quartet continues to play.
WILF and JEAN walking toward the backstage area with their canes.
Jean, our sticks. I think we should try to get through without them.
I’m not sure I can. My hip’s very bad tonight.
I’m not sure I can either. But I think we should try. It would be more dignified. More operatic.
I may have to lean on you.
Lean on Reg, it’d be safer. And he’d be very pleased. He adores you. (she looks doubtful) Trust me. They enter backstage.
(whispering) Does he?
(whispering) Of course he does. I don’t think Reg has ever stopped loving you.

How do you know? Has he said so? JEAN catches REGGIE’S eye. The String Quartet is coming to the end of the movement. JEAN holds and then comes to him. They look at each other for a moment, then he looks away.  110
(meaningfully) At least you won't be singing at La Scala again.
No. Never again. Never again, Reggie.
Is that an apology?
It is. (she looks at him) You look very handsome tonight, Reg.
(turning back to her) And you look very beautiful, Jean.
And now we are old. A long look at JEAN from REGGIE.

(is it tongue in cheek?) Then let’s get married. The string quartet has just finished their last movement and the audience is applauding. After a moment, REGGIE Marches on the stage to an even bigger applause. INT. MAIN HALL —- DAY A BRIGHT SPOTLIGHT bursts onto REGGIE. The audience continues applauding, cheering and whistling. Some of the residents now stand or sit at the back and join in enthusiastically. REGGIE bows, puts on his reading glasses and produces pieces of paper.

Ladies and gentlemen, this afternoon, my three colleagues and I are hoping to transport you to times past. We have come to the conclusion, after much argument and discussion, that we are unchanged. At least in spirit. And that spirit is most intensely expressed when we sing. (MORE)

And so, on this 10th of October, the anniversary of Guiseppe Verdi, I hope you will be moved by the glorious music. Rigoletto is one of Verdi's masterpieces. And the quartet is one of the great milestones in the history of opera. So now it is time for me to make the introductions. I myself am, of course, the Duke of Mantua, and as Rigoletto, we are fortunate to have the popular, celebrated baritone, Mr. Wilfred Bond. WILFRED walks on without cane to great applause and bows. When he straightens up:
And, as Maddalena, our own, our very own, the delicious Miss Cecily Robson. CISSY enters and curtsies to great applause and cheers.

And last, but not least, one of the great stars in the operatic firmament for whom, I know, you have all been waiting, please welcome as Gilda, the great, the incomparable, Miss Jean Horton. JEAN enters, without cane, walking with difficulty, can barely curtsey to the great applause and cheers.
